result.execSummary:
The defendant Brian Scott Wittenberg was found guilty of the following charge(s) in this case.

  • Disorderly Conduct. This is not a criminal offense and results only in a money penalty for this offense.

Notice to employers: It may be a violation of state law to discriminate against a job applicant because of an arrest or conviction record. Generally speaking, an employer may refuse to hire an applicant on the basis of a conviction only if the circumstances of the conviction substantially relate to the particular job. For more information, see Wisconsin Statute 111.335 and the Department of Workforce Development's publication, Arrest and Conviction Records under the Law.

judgments.action: Guilty Due to No Contest Plea

charges.dispoDesc: Guilty Due to No Contest Plea

result.caption: State of Wisconsin vs. Brian Scott Wittenberg

records.addlTxt:
Defendant Brian Scott Wittenberg in court with attorney John Stephen Joyce.  Tristan J. Bednarek appeared for the State of Wisconsin.
Case set for a jury trial. 

As to COUNT 1: On motion of the state, the court amended the charge to Disorderly Conduct, contrary to Milwaukee County Ordinance, 63.01. to which the defendant plead no contest. Court finds defendant guilty of amended charge.  Court orders a forfeiture in the amount of $150.00 including costs to be paid by 11/8/22, cash bail to apply. Any remaining cash bail on deposit to be returned to the poster. Failure to pay will result in a civil judgment.

Defendant Brian Scott Wittenberg in court with attorney Matthew Adrian Lamke.  Defendant Brian Scott Wittenberg in custody.  Jennifer Jean Tate appeared for the State of Wisconsin.  Brian Scott Wittenberg appeared by video means with Attorney.  Defendant is advised this case is assigned to Judge Kiefer, Branch 29. Court reviewed the complaint and found probable cause.  Defendant advised of right to counsel and complaint given to defendant's attorney.  Court enter pleas of not guilty to count 1. Court reserves defendant rights of substitution.  DEFENDANT DOES NOT QUALIFY FOR PUBLIC DEFENDER REPRESENTATION IF RELEASED FROM CUSTODY.
